prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text: Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you— / a whisper beneath the skin of silence, / where roots coil in dark communion. / I have spent years deaf to your pulse, / mistaking echo for voice, / shadow for substance. / But now, in the hush between breaths, / I catch your cadence—low, insistent, / like rain tapping on buried stone. / To speak you, Truth, I must first kneel / in the soil of my own stillness, / let the noise of the world dissolve. / For you are not proclaimed, but uncovered— / a seed cracked open by attention. / I learn your language not in speech, but in surrender: / the rustle of leaves accepting wind, / the creek naming its course without question. / If I dwell in the quiet long enough, / you will rise in me like dawn— / not with fanfare, but with light so steady / it turns night into memory. / Then, and only then, / shall my lips shape you / not as declaration, but as devotion.

In the cathedral of silence, Truth, I seek your altar. / I have worn the mask of knowing, / yet spoke only in borrowed syllables. / You said: 'I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,' / and I trembled—for how long have I shouted / into the void, mistaking noise for communion? / Listening is not passive; it is pilgrimage. / It is sitting with the ache of not-knowing, / letting questions root deeper than answers. / You dwell not in the thunder, but in the pause after— / in the space where ego dissolves. / To speak you, Truth, I must first unlearn my tongue, / let it grow calloused from prayer, not pride. / I will sit at your feet in stillness, / until my bones remember your rhythm. / Then, from that depth, a word may rise— / not mine, but ours: / a single syllable of dawn.

Truth, you are not a sword to brandish, / but a well to draw from—deep, cool, hidden. / I cannot speak you with clenched fists or lifted chin. / Only when my ears press to the earth, / when I cease my endless naming, / do you stir in the hush. / 'I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you'— / a paradox that cracks me open. / For years I sought you in speeches, scriptures, summits, / but you dwell in the hum beneath sound, / in the breath before thought. / Listening is my penance, my prayer, my path. / It is the discipline of presence, / the courage to hear what I fear— / the silence that speaks louder than lies. / And when I am fluent in stillness, / when my soul is tuned to your frequency, / then—soft as moss on stone— / you will rise in my voice, / not as conquest, but as confession.

You said: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,' / and the world tilted. / Not on its axis, but on the fulcrum of attention. / For how can I utter what I’ve never truly heard? / I have been a loud believer in noise, / mistaking volume for virtue. / But truth wears no megaphone. / She walks barefoot through the thicket of the unnoticed, / leaves no footprints, only resonance. / To speak her, I must become her student— / sit with the ache of ambiguity, / let questions live in me like guests, not intruders. / Listening is the quiet rebellion, / the refusal to rush, to fix, to fabricate. / It is the art of waiting until the water clears. / And when at last I hear her—faint as a pulse in stone— / then my voice may become her vessel, / not in triumph, but in trembling.

Truth, I have chased you like a storm, / but you are the calm after. / I have shouted your name into canyons, / but you answer only in whispers I must lean in to catch. / 'I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you'— / a vow spun from humility. / For speech without listening is echo, / a hollow ring without source. / So I train my ears in the monastery of now, / where distraction is the only devil, / and stillness, the only scripture. / I learn to hear you in the space between heartbeats, / in the rustle of leaves that ask for nothing, / in the gaze of a child who hasn’t yet learned to lie. / Listening becomes my liturgy. / And when I am steeped in your silence, / when my soul is porous and open, / then—like dew on grass at dawn— / you will glisten on my tongue, / not as possession, but as gift.

responses.text: A hush before the syllable is born,  / When silence leans close to the speaker's ear—  / Not words that leap, but truths withdrawn,  / That rise when doubt has left the atmosphere.  / I've worn the noise of opinions like a coat,  / But warmth came not from fabric, nor from sound,  / Until I stood, disrobed of thought,  / And let the still small voice move through the ground.  / Truth! In the cathedral of quiet, where echoes retire,  / I vowed to utter you, Truth, but only if heard—  / Not plucked from sky like lightning, nor forged in fire,  / But drawn from the hush where all answers are blurred.  / I wore voices like masks, each one a disguise,  / Till I stood bare before the well without name,  / And lowered my bucket through shadow and skies,  / Not seeking an answer, but learning to frame  / The shape of your breath beneath my own.  / Now I know: to speak you, I must first obey—  / To listen not with intent to respond or atone,  / But to let you arrive at the edge of the day.  / So I wait in the hush, where the real things begin,  / And whisper, when ready: I let you come in.

So here I stand, unloud,  / And whisper: I heard you. Now speak through my blood.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

Blessed be Thou for simple things—the cat curled on the sill, the book well-loved, the quiet walk beside the rippling hill. For reunions after years, for letters from afar, for music that can make us weep beneath a single star. Blessed be Thou for joy that rises not from what we own, but in the knowing we are seen, and never left alone. For moments when the world stands still and beauty takes our breath, for tasting heaven in a kiss, a sunset, or a death. Blessed be Thou for all the joy that threads through human days—like sunlight through cathedral glass in unexpected ways. Everyone has a fear, a secret they guard, / Like thorns on a rose, both fragile and hard. / It sleeps in the corners of laughter and light, / A phantom that haunts the edge of the night. / Some fear the unknown, the path not yet trod, / Others the known—the ache of old sod. / The fear of not mattering, vanishing slow, / Or becoming a ghost in the place you once know. / Fear of heights, of depths, of what lies within, / Of letting new chapters begin. / It trembles in voices that dare not confess, / In silences thick with unspoken stress. / Yet fear is not evil—it shapes who we are, / A compass, a wound, a guiding star. / For every 'what if' carries a spark, / A courage that glows in the gathering dark. / So name your fear, look it straight in the eye— / And whisper, 'You're part of me, but not why I fly.'

Everyone has a fear, a ghost in the hall, / That echoes through moments both minor and tall. / It breathes in the pause before 'yes' or 'no,' / In the seeds of regret that begin to grow. / One fears being trapped, another set free, / One dreads the future, one the memory. / Fear of change, of stillness, of being too much, / Of never quite measuring up. / It lives in the tremble of hands held too tight, / In the smile masking inner night. / But fear, though heavy, can teach us to rise— / To see our own strength with clearer eyes. / It carves out compassion, deepens the soul, / Makes brokenness part of the whole. / So when fear appears, don't turn and retreat— / Invite it to dance on unsteady feet. / For even in trembling, there's beauty and grace, / And courage is born in that fragile space.

Everyone has a fear, a knot in the thread, / That weaves through the life we are living and said. / It hides in plain sight, in routines and rhyme, / A heartbeat too fast out of sync with time. / Some fear abandonment, silence, or sound, / The loss of a name, or never being found. / One fears the mirror, another the past, / One dreads the die cast, one the die not cast. / Fear of speaking, of staying, of going away, / Of night turning into endless day. / Yet fear is not foreign—it's human, it's true, / A part of the spectrum in me and in you. / It sharpens the senses, ignites the will, / Turns 'cannot' to 'might' on a steeper hill. / So when fear knocks gently, don't bolt the door— / Let it in, let it speak, then ask for more: / 'What wisdom do you bring from the edge of the deep?' / And listen. Then gently, release it to sleep.

Everyone has a fear, a storm in the bone, / That rattles the house but leaves walls still stone. / It hums in the blood when the world feels too wide, / A tide pulling back from the shore of pride. / Fear of failure, of judgment, of love turned to lies, / Of seeing the truth through hollow eyes. / One fears commitment, another the flight, / One dreads the dark, one the blinding light. / It lives in the pause before 'I love you,' / In dreams where the sky turns bruise-colored blue. / But fear is not foe—it's a teacher, a guide, / A wave to be surfed, not a thing to hide. / For every deep terror holds seeds of the brave, / The strength to be gentle, the will to be saved. / So greet your fear gently, with kindness and grace, / Acknowledge its presence, give it time and space. / Then step forward anyway—trembling, but tall— / For courage is fear that decides to stand tall.

When I am happy, the air turns to honey, / Thick with the scent of lilac and money— / Not coins, but the wealth of a moment well spent, / A breath fully lived, a heart heaven-sent. / The pavement becomes a piano of dreams, / Each step plays a chord in sunlit streams. / Windows reflect not my face but my soul, / Bright as a bell and beautifully whole. / I talk to the sparrows, and they understand, / Nodding in rhythm to life’s gentle hand. / The grocery list turns to poetry, / 'Milk and bread' sings with melody. / Time slows its gallop, the world grows kind, / Even my shadow is light behind. / When I am happy, I am not alone— / The breeze carries seeds of a world I’ve outgrown. / And though it will pass, as all feelings do, / I store this joy like morning dew.

When I am happy, the sky wears my grin, / Clouds puff like pillows let loose from within. / The wind does cartwheels across the wide blue, / And even the pigeons look elegant, too. / My thoughts are not thoughts—they’re kites on a string, / Soaring with no need for anything. / The sidewalk blooms into carpets of light, / Each crack a river, each stone a bright kite. / I pass a stranger, and we share a glance— / A silent agreement: life’s in a dance. / No music required, just pulse and delight, / Two hearts in rhythm, both taking flight. / When I am happy, the world knows my name, / Whispered by trees, called out by flame. / The stars lean closer, the moon starts to glow— / Not just observing, but joining the show. / And if sorrow returns, as it sometimes must, / I’ll carry this light in my dust.

When I am happy, the walls fade away, / And ceilings dissolve into soft, silver day. / My body’s a vessel of light and of song, / A bird that’s been waiting its whole life to belong. / The clock on the wall stops pretending to know, / Time isn’t measured in minutes, but glow. / I touch the teacup, and warmth climbs my arm, / A ripple of comfort, a soft, human charm. / The cat stretches slow in a puddle of sun, / Mirroring joy that can’t be outrun. / Even my silence is loud with a tune, / A hum from the heart beneath the moon. / When I am happy, the world feels like home, / Not built of brick, but of moments I own. / And though joy is fleeting, like petals uncurled, / It teaches the soul how to sing to the world.

When I am happy, the air fills with wings— / Not birds, but the joy that the spirit sings. / The streetlamp flickers a Morse code of glee, / And puddles reflect a more colorful me. / My footsteps compose a spontaneous rhyme, / A beat born of wonder, outside of time. / The grocery bags swing like chandeliers, / And even my keys shed their ordinary fears. / I smile at the mailman, he winks back with grace, / As if we both know we’re winning this race. / Not toward finish lines, but into the now— / A sacred surrender, a sacred vow. / When I am happy, the mundane takes flight, / A dishrag becomes a banner of light. / And though clouds may gather, and shadows return, / This joy is a fire that continues to burn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text: When I am happy, the world hums low, a lullaby spun from golden light. The air tastes of ripe peaches, warm from the sun, and every shadow dances with hidden delight. My footsteps tap a rhythm on dew-kissed grass, a syncopated joy the morning can’t outrun. Laughter spills like water over smooth river stones, echoing in chambers where silence once held throne. The sky, a canvas of endless blue, holds clouds like tufts of dandelion dreams, drifting without care. I breathe in the scent of earth after rain, even when skies are clear—memory and magic entwined. When I am happy, time slows to a sway, cradling each moment like a treasured refrain. Even the wind leans close, whispering secrets only joy can translate. I am not just living—I am blooming, a flower unfurling toward no particular sun, simply because it can. This happiness isn't loud; it’s a quiet hum beneath the ribs, a steady pulse beneath skin. It needs no reason, no cause, no name—only presence, like breath, like tide, like flame.

When I am happy, the corners of the world soften. Walls dissolve into meadows, clocks forget their hands. I float through rooms filled with invisible music, each step a note in a private symphony. The kettle sings back when I whistle. Shadows stretch long and friendly, like old companions waving from the porch. My heart wears wings too small to carry me far, but large enough to lift me above doubt. I see patterns in spilled coffee, stories in sidewalk cracks. A pigeon strutting down the street becomes a noble knight. When I am happy, the ordinary glows—light through a glass of water, the curve of a spoon, the way dust motes swirl in afternoon gold. I speak to trees and believe they answer. I forgive old wounds without ceremony. The past loses its teeth. When I am happy, I am not searching. I am found. Found in the rustle of leaves, in a child’s unguarded giggle, in the warmth of a cat curled on my lap. I am not trying to be more or less. I simply am—a breath, a blink, a bloom. And in that being, everything sings back.

When I am happy, the sky leans down to kiss my shoulder. Clouds wear halos of apricot and rose, stitched into the fabric of dusk. My thoughts unclench, like fists opening to release butterflies. I walk barefoot through evening grass, each blade a cool whisper against my soles. The world becomes a poem I didn’t know I could write—lines unfolding in the sway of trees, in the distant chime of a bicycle bell. Even silence feels rich, layered with the hum of crickets and the promise of stars. I remember nothing heavy. Grief folds itself into origami birds and flies away. When I am happy, I am generous with smiles, offering them to strangers like wildflowers picked from no one’s garden. I dance in doorways, spin in circles until the sky blurs into paint. My reflection grins back, unafraid. Time doesn’t slip; it pools, warm and still, like sunlight on tile. I do not need to speak—the air knows my joy. When I am happy, I am not chasing. I am home. Not in a house, but in my skin, in this breath, in the quiet thunder of being alive.

When I am happy, the air thickens with honeyed light. Each breath is a sip from a golden cup, spilling warmth into my veins. The world sharpens and softens all at once—edges glisten, colors sing. A sparrow’s chirp becomes a sonnet. The rustle of pages, a symphony. I notice the way steam curls from my tea like a question mark, and I laugh, because for once, I have no need to answer. When I am happy, memories don’t haunt—they visit, gentle and brief, like old friends passing by. I forgive the past its stumbles. I trust the future to hold its breath. My hands feel useful, capable of building or holding or simply resting, palms open to the sky. I write love letters to no one in particular. I hum tunes that have no names. When I am happy, the weight of being human lifts, not gone, but transformed—wings instead of chains. I walk as if the ground remembers my name. Even shadows feel kind. And when night comes, it drapes over me like a velvet cloak, not hiding, but honoring the glow within. I am not perfect. But I am present. And in this moment, that is everything.

When I am happy, the universe winks. Rainbows flicker in oil-slick puddles. A cracked sidewalk blooms with imaginary flowers. My pulse syncs with the heartbeat of the city—the rumble of buses, the chatter of sparrows, the distant laughter from an open window. I carry joy like a lantern, casting soft light on everything it touches. A stranger’s smile becomes a gift. A shared umbrella, a sacrament. When I am happy, I forget to worry about meaning. I simply float in the current of now. The past is a quiet river behind me. The future, a path dusted with starlight. I dance in the kitchen while stirring soup. I talk to the moon like an old confidant. My skin tingles with the electricity of simple things—the brush of cotton, the scent of basil, the weight of a book in my hands. When I am happy, I am not trying to be seen. I am simply seeing—really seeing—the world in all its fragile, fleeting beauty. And in that seeing, I am seen. Not by eyes, but by the quiet hum of existence itself. I am not grand. I am small. And in my smallness, I am infinite.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text: Before me stands I see, a shadow tall and wide,  A figure carved from moonlight and from fear,  Its edges blurred as though the wind applied  A breath that whispered truths I long held dear.  It wears my face, yet wears it like a mask,  As if the soul behind has slipped away,  Replaced by echoes from a fading task—  The dreams I shelved, the words I failed to say.  I reach to touch, but my hand meets only air,  A cold that bites like winter's earliest breath.  The silence deepens, heavy with a prayer  That neither life nor death can quite bequeath.  And still it stands, unmoving, calm, and wise,  Reflecting not my form, but my disguise.  Before me stands I see—not flesh, not bone—  But all I was, and all I might have grown.

Before me stands I see a door of glass,  Transparent, yet I cannot pass it through.  Behind it walks a version of my past,  With eyes that gleam with what I thought I knew.  He smiles, but it's a smile I don’t recall,  A joy untouched by time or consequence.  He never fell, he never had to crawl  Through grief’s long night or loss’s dense suspense.  I knock, but sound does not escape my knuckles.  He turns, as if he hears, but does not come.  His life is whole, while mine bears old brambles  Of choices made beneath a clouded sun.  Before me stands I see the path I spared—  The love I left, the art I never dared.  A silent twin, untouched by compromise,  Living the dream I buried with a sigh.

Before me stands I see a mirror cracked,  Each shard a life I lived or might have led.  One shows me crowned, another dragged and sacked,  A father, hermit, poet, soldier, head  Of nations or of none. The glass still hums  With voices from the roads I didn’t take.  A chorus of what-ifs, their presence numbs—  The weight of every breath I dared not make.  I press my palm to one that shows me free,  A wanderer beneath eternal skies.  It warms beneath my touch, as though it sees  The part of me that longs to rise and fly.  Before me stands I see not just a face,  But every version time refused to place.  The mirror breathes. I wonder—do I choose,  Or do these fragments slowly choose their muse?

Before me stands I see a tree grown old,  Its bark inscribed with names I used to bear—  The child who danced, the youth with heart of gold,  The lover lost to silence and despair.  Its branches stretch like arms that once reached out  To grasp the stars, to hold a fleeting hand.  Now roots dig deep where sorrow laid its drought,  Yet still it stands, a monument unplanned.  Leaves fall like letters never sent or read,  Each one a thought I kept too long inside.  The wind recites them in a voice I dread—  My own, but wiser, weathered, amplified.  Before me stands I see my history,  Not carved in stone, but shaped by storm and tree.  And in its shadow, I begin to grow,  Not forward, but into the roots below.

Before me stands I see a flame alight,  Not burning wood, but memories undone.  It flickers with the colors of the night—  Deep blue of grief, bright gold of someone  Who dared to hope. The fire does not warm,  But draws me near with magnetic grace.  It shows a child untouched by worldly storm,  A future bright I failed to interlace.  The blaze speaks not in words, but in a glow  That pulses like a heartbeat in the dark.  It knows the names of every place I go  To hide the ember fading in my heart.  Before me stands I see what still remains—  Not ash, but light that dances through the stains.  A quiet voice within the crackling sound:  'You’re more than all the ground you’ve left unturned.'

Before me stands I see the ghost of might-have-been, / A silhouette stitched from should-have-been. / Tall in the dusk, with eyes like embers dim, / He wears the coat I never let love in. / His hands are scarred from battles I refused, / His voice, a song I never dared to use. / Yet in his stance, a kinship starts to bloom— / He is my exile, I am his tomb. / We share the breath that trembles in the air, / Two halves of one who couldn't quite repair. / He does not blame, nor beg, nor turn to flee— / He simply stands, and lets me see. / And in that gaze, a question starts to grow: / If I step forward, will he let me go? / Or will we merge, at last, in quiet peace— / Before me stands I see… and I release.

Before me stands I see a tree of years, / Its roots sunk deep in laughter, soaked in tears. / Bark etched with names I gave myself at dawn— / The dreamer, fool, the lover nearly gone. / Its branches stretch with letters never sent, / With crowns I wore and gave to disappointment. / Leaves shimmer gold with moments I let slide, / While winds of fear kept truth locked deep inside. / Yet still it grows, though bent and split with time, / Defiant in its slow, enduring climb. / No fruit, perhaps, as others might have borne, / But seeds of grace from every bruise and thorn. / Before me stands I see—not just a tree, / But life that chose to be, despite not free. / And in its shade, I finally breathe, / Knowing my scars are where I truly breathe.

Before me stands I see the child I knew— / Barefoot on dew, with skies of endless blue. / He smiles, not knowing all the falls ahead, / The words that cut, the love that left unsaid. / His eyes are wide with trust I’ve learned to cage, / His heart still beats with unbetrayed age. / I want to warn him, shield him from the rain, / But time won’t bend, and joy must bear the pain. / Instead, I kneel and whisper soft and low: / 'You’ll lose some light, but never stop to grow. / You’ll wear new names, forget your native song, / But deep within, you’ll know where you belong.' / He nods, as if he’s known it all along. / Before me stands I see—and I feel strong. / For though I’ve changed, he lives beneath my skin, / A quiet flame that darkness can’t shut in.

Before me stands I see the path I’ve worn— / A trail of echoes, tattered, yet forlorn. / Not straight, nor grand, but etched with stumbling grace, / Each footprint shaped by time and quiet chase. / I trace the turns where courage nearly died, / The crossroads where I ran, or chose to hide. / Yet here and there, a stone gleams soft with light— / A hand once held, a star that pierced the night. / The road ahead is veiled in mist and dew, / But now I walk with older, kinder view. / For every scar the past has carved in me, / Has taught my soul how deep it dares to be. / Before me stands I see—not just the tread, / But every step that led me here, well-fed / On loss and love, on breaking and rebirth. / And so I walk, no longer chasing worth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text: Fire: a tongue that speaks without sound, licking the air with crimson hymns. It devours the hush of night, casting shadows that dance like ancient priests in ritual. Sparks rise like forgotten prayers, spiraling toward a heaven they’ll never touch. In its glow, time warps—wood becomes ash, memory becomes myth. I have seen lovers trace promises in the smoke, only for the wind to erase them. Fire does not care for oaths. It consumes the log, the letter, the photograph—equal in its hunger. Yet in winter’s grip, it sings warmth into frozen bones, a paradox of destruction and comfort. It shaped civilizations, forged swords and bread alike. Prometheus stole it for us, and we’ve been burning ever since—our wars, our stoves, our restless hearts. Fire is the first storyteller, painting epics on cave walls with flickering light. It waits in matches, in lightning, in the friction of two stones. One spark, and the world remembers its oldest language. Even when it dies, it leaves embers—tiny red eyes watching from the dark, whispering: I was here. I was alive.

Fire: a pulse in the dark, restless and raw. It crackles like bones underfoot, a language older than words. It does not ask permission—it takes, transforms, leaves behind the skeleton of what was. I think of bonfires on beaches, where laughter rises with the smoke, and secrets are tossed into the flames like kindling. Fire forgives nothing. It turns paper to ghost, wood to charcoal, dreams to cinder. Yet we gather around it, drawn like moths, seeking its truth. It teaches us impermanence: no blaze lasts forever. Even the sun will one day cool. But oh, the beauty in its rage—the way it dances, untamed, painting the sky in hues of vengeance and passion. Fire is both end and beginning. prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text: Loss can be good for us, they say, though bitter its taste, / Like winter stripping trees bare, leaving branches to face / The open sky, unshielded, yet stronger for it. / In emptiness, we find the shape of what we truly commit / Our hearts to—what remains when all pretense is gone. / A hollowed nest still holds the echo of song. / We learn the weight of silence, the grace in letting be, / And discover depths within us we never thought to see. / For every door that closes, a different path appears, / Not paved with gold, but with wisdom earned through tears. / The self we thought was whole was built on borrowed ground; / Loss clears the way for roots to strike where truth is found. / We grieve, yes, and rightly—grief is love with nowhere to go— / But in that ache, a seed of transformation may grow. / Not all wounds scar; some open into light. / Loss, though cruel, can set the soul alight.

In the quiet after leaving, when echoes start to fade, / We find a space not empty, but gently remade. / Loss can be good for us, though it cuts like frost, / For in the absence blooms a strength we thought was lost. / Like rivers carving canyons with patient, steady flow, / Pain shapes the contours of who we come to know. / The things we lose—a person, dream, or time— / Leave imprints that sharpen our sense of rhyme. / Not every end is barren; some are fallow fields, / Resting for the harvest that the heart eventually yields. / We learn to carry less, to value what is true, / To see the world with clearer, kinder, humbler view. / Gratitude arises where longing used to dwell. / In learning how to lose, we learn how to heal. / And though the wound may linger, it teaches us to grow— / Loss, in its sorrow, helps the genuine self show.

They whisper, 'Loss can be good for us,' and we scoff, / Clutching memories like coals, our fingers burned, our hearts rough. / Yet seasons turn—spring dares to bloom in soot and ash, / And from the wreckage, something tender starts to clash / With grief's dark tide. Not joy, not yet, but peace— / A knowing that release can bring a slow increase / Of self. For in losing, we are stripped to bone, / No masks, no roles, just essence, standing all alone. / And in that solitude, a voice: not loud, but clear— / The one we buried under years of fear. / Loss dismantles illusion, the false that we held dear. / It teaches us to breathe in thinner, purer air. / Not that we welcome pain or praise the hurt we bear, / But through the cracks, a different kind of light comes there.

When all is taken—name, place, face, or flame— / And silence fills the rooms that once knew your name, / There lies a strange alchemy in the ache: / A self long buried starts to reawaken. / Loss can be good for us, not in a way that sings, / But like the soil that feeds on fallen things. / The heart, once broken, learns a deeper beat, / A rhythm forged in sorrow, steady, slow, and sweet. / We shed the weight of what we could not keep, / And in that lightness, find the strength to leap / Not toward forgetting, but toward becoming— / A soul reshaped by love, by absence, by summing / The cost of care, the worth of what was true. / Loss carves the vessel; love fills it anew. / And though the scar remains, it maps the grace / Of having loved enough to leave an empty space.

Loss can be good for us, though it feels like the end, / A key turned in a lock we can't pretend / To understand. The world dims, colors fade, / And yet—beneath the shadow, roots are laid. / For comfort breeds complacency; ease can dull the soul, / But sorrow wakes the spirit, makes it whole / In ways we never sought. We see with clearer eyes, / Value the brief bloom, cherish goodbyes. / We learn to hold lightly, love more deeply, speak more true. / The things we lose teach us what we’re willing to lose. / Not all gain is progress; not all loss is fall. / Sometimes the breaking opens space for all / That was too small to breathe inside the shell. / Grief is not the opposite of joy, but its twin— / And in their dance, we learn where we begin.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text: Please spare me your secrets, whispered in shadows, / Heavy as stones, yet lighter than breath. / I do not want the weight of your sorrows, / The ghosts in your voice, the dance with death. / Let them linger where silence grows deep, / In the hush between heartbeats, in dreams you can't keep. / For I carry my own unspoken fears, / Tangled in roots through the silent years. / Your confessions bloom like nightshade flowers, / Beautiful, toxic, stealing my hours. / I would rather know you in sunlight and laughter, / In simple gestures, not truths that come after. / So keep your wounds wrapped in velvet and lies, / Let your mysteries drift through indifferent skies. / I do not need your soul laid bare— / Just your hand in mine, the cool evening air.

Please spare me your secrets, I beg, / They cling like smoke, they dig and peg / Roots in my chest, not mine to hold, / Stories too sharp, too brave, too bold. / I am a vessel already full— / With my own ghosts, my own dull pull / Toward silence, toward self-made walls. / Your truth could shatter my fragile halls. / So let us meet where surfaces gleam, / On the edge of a smile, in the light of a dream. / I love you enough to say, 'Let them be'— / Your shadows are sacred. Just stay close to me.
